title-group.article-title: Sheep femoral artery occlusion is well tolerated and does not result in ischemia

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Sheep are commonly used as large animal pre‐clinical models for investigating cardiovascular therapies, interventions, anatomy and physiology. Further, novel small diameter vascular grafts are frequently tested via implantation into sheep carotid arteries (CAs). This is because, unlike humans, acute occlusion of one or both sheep CAs is not associated with morbidity or mortality and thus provides safer experimental testing, with reduced ethical constraints, animal numbers and costs. However, to date there has been no evidence regarding sheep tolerance of femoral artery (FA) occlusion.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In this study, seven sheep underwent CA graft surgery, with digital subtraction angiography (DSA) of the CAs performed every 2 months via femoral access, for a total of 8 months. Four months into the study, the left FA of two sheep became inaccessible due to a suspected FA occlusion. Thus, femoral angiography was performed, followed by FA dissection, FA histology and retrospective analysis of both veterinarian animal monitoring and pain scores.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: FA angiography and histology confirmed complete left FA occlusion in two sheep. Retrospective animal monitoring demonstrated sheep with occluded FAs did not display increased pain scores or deleterious effects on their gait or wellbeing.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our data shows that sheep tolerate FA occlusion with no symptoms, similar to their cerebral circulation, making them an appropriate model for assessing small diameter femoral graft interposition studies and testing other cardiovascular interventions.

abstract.p: Left femoral artery occlusion (yellow arrows) can be seen shortly after the lateral femoral circumflex artery origin, with distal arterial reconstitution. Sheep with femoral artery occlusion showed no change in pain scores nor mobility, thus making them an appropriate model for novel small diameter femoral artery graft studies.

institution-wrap.institution: The Baird Institute for applied Heart and Lung Research

p.mixed-citation: ShiraevT, WangZ, SethL, et al. Sheep femoral artery occlusion is well tolerated and does not result in ischemia. Anim Models Exp Med. 2025;8:1313‐1320. doi:10.1002/ame2.70065PMC1243156640641376

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Large‐animal models are necessary for pre‐clinical assessments of cardiovascular interventions, such as new bypass conduits or arterial pathology. Sheep and pigs are the most commonly used proxy for the human cardiovascular system, due the size of both the overall animal and their vessels. 1 Unlike pigs, sheep are anatomically closer to humans and stop growing at adulthood. Further, sheep are behaviourally easier to manage in the peri‐operative period when compared to other animals. 2 Of interest, they tend to be hypercoagulable relative to humans due to relative polycythemia, increased platelet adhesiveness and reduced fibrinolysis. 3 To manage this, intra‐operative heparin must be given at higher doses than in humans. Further, neither aspirin nor clopidogrel are effective platelet inhibitors in sheep. 4 , 5

The ascending aorta of the sheep is short, causing difficulty with cardiopulmonary bypass cannulation as well as the proximal anastomoses in coronary bypasses. 6 In addition, coronary surgery adds procedure time and significant morbidity. As a result, assessments of bypass graft function in ovine carotid vessels are an appropriate model for both peripheral and cardiac bypasses. 2 , 3 Furthermore, over 20% of small diameter (≤6 mm) prosthetic grafts fail in less than 1 year in humans, 7 and hence the ovine carotid interposition model is ideal for testing novel small diameter grafts. The carotid artery (CA) is often used in these models due to its relatively superficial location, making surgical access easier than other locations. In addition, there is significant ovine tolerance for CA occlusions, which can occur due to surgical manipulation, or thrombosis of the bypass. 3 , 8 However, we have previously demonstrated that significant spasm is seen with manipulation of the carotid vasculature. 9 This results in direct carotid puncture for angiography being at high risk of CA thrombosis, occlusion, or artefactually slower flow. As a result, percutaneous femoral access for CA angiography is preferred. In addition, as ovine femoral arteries (FAs) are both smaller and have lower flow rates than the CA, 3 and lower limb interventions in humans are much more common than carotid interventions, 10 the FA may be a more accurate model for smaller diameter conduits.

With any intervention on a surgical model, there is concern that occlusion of the FA may occur due to occlusion of a novel femoral graft, or a complication of percutaneous femoral access. This occlusion may then lead to morbidity such as chronic pain, limb loss, or the need for euthanasia, with resulting ethical, financial and experimental implications. Although acute occlusion of ovine carotid vessels is not associated with any negative sequelae for the animal, 3 there is little evidence regarding the ischemic tolerance of the hindleg in sheep. This study demonstrates that, following FA occlusion, sheep have an excellent tolerance for hindleg ischemia, similar to that seen in their carotid circulation. Thus, we suggest sheep FAs are an ideal surgical model for testing novel cardiovascular interventions, such as small diameter graft interventions.

sec.title: Animal care and ethics
sec.p: This study was approved by the University of Sydney Animal Ethics Committee (protocol ID 2023/2353) and animals were cared for within animal ethis committee guidelines, ensuring consideration of animal welfare as per the NHMRC code. 11 Seven male Merino‐cross White Suffolk wethers, 1–2 years of age were used for this study. Weight before commencement of the study was 45.6–55.0 kg (mean 49.7 ± 3.1 kg), and weight at study completion was 49.7–68.1 kg (mean 55.6 ± 6.9 kg). The sheep were acclimatized for 14 days before study commencement, with a 12 hour light‐cycle. They were housed in groups, and fed a diet of hay and oaten‐chaff with free access to water. Sheep were then fasted for 12 hours before anesthesia. Post‐operatively, the animals were recovered individually until fully awake, before being re‐introduced to their original housing, where they underwent assessment and care by the veterinarians.

sec.title: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) of the carotid arteries (CAs)
sec.p: CA implantation and imaging was performed as previously described. 9 Briefly, during patency analyses of a novel arterial conduit inserted as a CA interposition graft, the sheep were induced with intravenous propofol, before general anesthesia was maintained with isoflurane and ketamine. DSA was then performed via retrograde ultrasound‐guided percutaneous femoral artery (FA) access using the Seldinger technique, 12 using sheaths ranging in size from five to seven French (Figure 1A, generated using BioRender software). Pigtail catheters were advanced to the ascending aorta over a Bentson wire (Cook Medical, Bloomington, IN, USA) and iodinated contrast was injected to obtain DSA (40 mL Omnipaque, power‐injected at 750 psi over 1.25 seconds) using a Siemens ARTIS Pheno Robotic C‐arm Angiography imaging system. Post‐procedure, hemostasis of the femoral access was obtained via either 15 or 20 min of digital pressure and icing, or the use of Starclose® or Prostyle® devices (Abbott Cardiovascular, Chicago, Il, USA) deployed under ultrasound guidance.

caption.p: Schematic of angiography procedures during investigations, with simplified pelvic anatomy. (A) During the initial imaging, percutaneous access was obtained via the left femoral artery, and a pigtail catheter introduced to the ascending aorta (AscA) to obtain imaging of the carotid arteries. Aorta, infra‐renal aorta; DFA, bilateral deep FAs; EIA, external iliac artery, FA, femoral artery. (B) At termination of the study, angiography was performed via the right FA. After imaging the carotids, the pigtail was withdrawn to the distal aorta, and bilateral iliac and femoral angiography performed to investigate for left FA occlusion (depicted).

sec.title: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) of the femoral arteries (FAs)
sec.p: Due to an inability to successfully introduce a femoral sheath to the left FA at Day 120 post‐carotid implant surgery in two sheep, there was suspicion of occlusion of the left FA. As a result, angiograms were performed on the FAs of all seven sheep before culling (day 240 post‐surgery). Contralateral (right) FA access was obtained for imaging of the carotid grafts and CAs. The pigtail catheter was then withdrawn to the distal aorta, and bilateral iliac/FA angiography was performed to diagnose left FA occlusion. If femoral occlusion was confirmed (Figure 1B), the occluded artery and the contralateral patent artery (as a control) were excised at completion of the study for histology. DSA images were processed for visualization using FIJI 13 imaging software.

sec.title: Sheep femoral artery (FA) histology
sec.p: The right and left FAs were harvested from sheep at the site of occlusion. The excised arteries were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF, Sigma, HT5012) for 24 hours, followed by 3 × 5 min washes in phosphate‐buffered saline (PBS, Sigma, P4417), and subsequently transferred to 70% ethanol for preservation. The fixed tissues were then processed and embedded in paraffin wax, followed by sectioning at 5 μm thickness using a microtome (Shandon™ Finesse™ 325, Thermo Scientific). For histopathological analysis, cross sections underwent Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and Verhoeff‐van Gieson staining: initial deparaffinization in 2 changes of xylene for 10 min each at room temperature followed by rehydration in graded ethanol solutions for 2 min each at room temperature, followed by Hematoxylin staining to highlight nuclei, and counterstaining with Eosin to visualize cytoplasmic components. Dehydrated slides also underwent Verhoeff's Hematoxylin staining for elastin fiber visualization and counterstaining with van Gieson stain for collagen and extracellular matrix components. The stained sections underwent rapid dehydration in 95% EtOH and 2 changes of 100% EtOH for 1 minute each and clearing through 2 changes of xylene for 2 min each. Finally, the stained sections were mounted with DPX mounting medium (Sigma, 06522) for microscopic examination. H&E stained slides were imaged on Nikon Ni‐E widefield microscope with DS‐Fi2 color camera. Verhoeff‐van Gieson stained slides were imaged using an Olympus VS200 slide scanner.

sec.title: Animal monitoring
sec.p: Sheep were monitored by veterinarians daily for 7 days post carotid surgery, 3 days post‐angiogram (performed every 2 months), then twice a week to the completion of the study. Sheep were also separately monitored twice a week by a research technician. Veterinarians used the validated Unesp‐Botucatu Composite 14 and Sheep Grimace Scales 15 throughout the study to assess pain, animal wellbeing and any need for additional analgesia. Pain scores for each sheep were collated and plotted against days post‐surgery using GraphPad Prism 10 software.

sec.title: Angiograms show sheep femoral artery (FA) occlusion following repeated FA catheter access
sec.p: For routine angiograms of the CAs in a separate study of CA interposition grafts, we performed percutaneous FA access and advanced a pigtail catheter to the ascending aorta (Figure 1A). This was performed every two months, alternating between the left and right FAs for catheter access. However, upon attempts to re‐image the grafts via angiography at Day 120 post‐surgery, the left FA in two sheep were suspected to be occluded due an inability to advance catheters along the FA. This occlusion was either due to repeated FA access causing intimal damage, or excess digital pressure upon sheath removal causing acute occlusion. To confirm occlusion, on routine Day 240 CA angiography imaging we retracted the pigtail catheter to the descending aorta (Figure 1B) and performed additional hind leg angiograms (Figure 2). In sheep that showed no signs of occlusion during FA access, hind leg angiograms confirmed fully patent femoral arterial trees (Figures 2 and 3A,B). In contrast, two sheep identified early as having suspected occlusions, showed left FA occlusions beginning 1–2 cm distal to the origin of the lateral femoral circumflex artery, with reconstitution of the FA distally (Figure 3C,D). Evidence of smaller diameter patent collateral arteries running around the site of occlusion were also observed (Figure 3C,D). Whether such collateral arteries were already present or formed from angiogenesis post‐occlusion is unknown, as they were not visible in patent angiograms. These data show the sheep FA can become occluded during routine FA access for angiography imaging.

caption.p: DSA image of sheep showing patent iliac and femoral arteries (FAs). Note that unlike humans, the external iliac artery branches from the aortic bifurcation, and the deep FA originates from the external iliac artery in the pelvis. 16 Aorta, infra‐renal aorta; CIA, common iliac artery; DFA, deep FA; DICA, deep iliac circumflex artery; EIA, external iliac artery; FA, femoral artery; IIA, internal iliac artery; LFCA, lateral femoral circumflex artery.

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) of bilateral ilio‐femoral arterial tree in sheep with and without left femoral artery (FA) occlusion. (A and B) DSA of sheep with bilateral patent FAs. (C and D) DSA of sheep with occluded left FAs and patent right FAs. Left FA occlusion (yellow arrows) can be seen to begin shortly after the lateral femoral circumflex artery origin with distal reconstitution. Imaging catheter can be seen traversing the right FA (dashed yellow arrows).

sec.title: Histology shows sheep femoral artery (FA) occlusion is due to thrombus formation
sec.p: For further confirmation and to characterize the occlusion, we collected the suspected occluded left FA and patent right FA for histological analyses (Figure 4). Hematoxlyin and Eosin staining showed a patent lumen in the right FA and a mixed fibrin and platelet‐rich thrombus in the occluded artery, with moderate cellular infiltrate within the occlusion. 17 Verhoeff‐van Gieson staining (which stains collagen pink and elastin fibers black) demonstrated the true vessel wall distance from the thrombus, and highlighted the luminal narrowing that had occurred secondary to chronic occlusion (Figure 4). In comparison to the patent contralateral (right) FA, near complete occlusion was observed, with a highly cellular intraluminal reaction. Further, the vessel diameter itself was reduced, and internal elastic lamina disruption was observed, as is known to occur in chronic arterial occlusions. 18

caption.p: Histopathologic examination shows tolerated left femoral artery (FA) occlusion. Hemotoxylin and Eosin (H&E; top two panels, nuclei = purple, cytoplasm/extracellular matrix = pink) and Verhoeff‐van Gieson staining (VVG; bottom two panels, elastin = black, collagen/thrombus = dark pink, nuclei = gray, cytoplasm = light brown) of right and left FAs from sheep imaged in Figure 3. Inflammation can be seen throughout the thrombus.

sec.title: Sheep tolerate femoral artery occlusion with no evidence of pain, ischemia or altered gait
sec.p: Throughout the study, pain scores were recorded by veterinarians (I.W. and the University of Sydney Laboratory Animal Services team) (Figure 5). As expected, there was mild pain after the implantation of the carotid interposition grafts (Day 0) that was controlled successfully with anti‐inflammatory medications (meloxicam 0.5 mg/kg oro‐transmucosally once daily), with pain normalizing by Day 3 post‐operatively. However, there was no alteration in pain levels or gait at any point after the imaging sessions, where percutaneous femoral access was performed. Given the inability to cannulate the left FA on Day 120, and visible FA occlusion on duplex ultrasound, it is likely that the occlusions occurred following the second post‐surgery imaging session (Day 60). Despite this, no pain nor behavioral differences were observed. The only peri‐operative complication was that a large femoral hematoma was encountered upon removal of the 7Fr femoral sheath on day 60 in one sheep, which required prolonged digital pressure. This sheep went on to suffer a femoral occlusion. The etiology of the femoral occlusion in the other sheep is unclear.

caption.p: Sheep show no increase in pain scores following femoral artery occlusion over 8 months post‐surgery monitoring. Sheep 5 and Sheep 7 (indicated by an asterix) suffered femoral occlusions after the imaging. Occurring on day 60, but pain scores demonstrate no alterations at or after this event. Further, no alterations in pain were seen at any other time points, suggesting it was the imaging sheath that caused the femoral occlusion. Sheep pain scores were determined by veterinarians using Unesp‐Botucatu Composite 14 and Sheep Grimace Scales. 15

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This study demonstrates that sheep have an excellent tolerance for hindleg ischemia, with occlusion of the left FA not effecting pain scores, gait or behavior. Similar findings are well described in dogs, with ligation of FAs causing no symptoms or complications in both the short 19 , 20 and medium term. 20 The lack of acute or chronic ischemic symptoms is possibly due to several factors. Firstly, the FAs likely have a well‐developed collateral network, as is seen in the ovine carotid circulation. 2 They also have a much larger deep FA than humans, almost equal in size to the main FA. As such, it is possible the collateral circulation via the deep femoral may compensate. Of interest, acute occlusion of one CA has been shown to result in systemic hypertension, in addition to significant increases in flow through the contralateral carotid and bilateral vertebral arteries. 8 In fact, contralateral occlusion resulted in an average increase in blood flow of 60% in the carotid, and 185% in the vertebral arteries. 8 As such, it is highly likely that the FAs have similar autoregulation in response to acute ischemia, but specific studies would be required to confirm this.

Our findings suggest sheep are an excellent model to assess the outcome of cardiovascular interventions, due to their tolerance of acute arterial occlusion in multiple vascular beds. The common CA in sheep ranges from 5.6 to 7.2 cm, while the FA is 4.2–5.0 cm, with half the mean flow rate. 3 As a result, the FA may be a better model for smaller diameter conduits, and may improve low flow state testing. Further, as the majority of peripheral vascular surgery involves the lower limbs, 10 a femoral rather than carotid model may be more appropriate. The FA also has the benefit of being relatively superficial and easy to access during open surgery. In addition, the FA is the preferred site of percutaneous access, due to its relative size, while being over a incompressible bony structure. Lastly, the FA is the usual site of open surgical bypasses, while carotid bypasses are rarely performed. For these reasons, the FA may be a more representative model of human bypasses than the CA.

Limitations of femoral access include that surgical access to the FA can require division of the sartorius (so increasing post‐operative pain for the animal), and a femoral incision is accessible for the animal to masticate sutures post‐operatively, risking wound complications. While an alternative is to use the graft to form an arteriovenous fistula, 21 avoiding the risk to distal tissue, this would result in different flow dynamics, including reduced downstream resistance, and so may artefactually improve patency. Further, if testing bypass patency, there may be different vascular cells seeding the graft from the venous anastomosis, altering its physiology.

While arterial occlusion is a potential complication of these interventions, every effort should still be made to maintain patency of ovine arteries. During the session of angiography prior to the diagnosis of femoral occlusion in one of the sheep, a closure device was not used, and digital pressure was used for hemostasis instead. This resulted in a large hematoma and required a long period of pressure over the FA to resolve. The authors hypothesize that during this period of digital pressure, the FA was inadvertently occluded. This suggests that percutaneous FA closure devices (as used in the majority of the angiography sessions) may reduce the incidence of FA occlusion, when compared to digital pressure only. In human meta‐analyses, use of vascular closure devices reduced time to hemostasis and ambulation, with suggestions of reductions in major vascular complications and bleeding complications. 22 While the downside of vascular closure devices includes cost and the need for training to use them correctly, the potential for reduction in complications, and reduction in total procedure time makes them worth considering when performing percutaneous angiography.

A limitation of this study is the small sample size. This is a common limitation of large animal studies due to their high cost. This was exacerbated by the FA occlusion being an incidental finding, rather than a deliberate experimental occlusion group. While future studies with planned FA occlusion and assessment of outcomes would have ethical implications, future assessment could be achieved by further observational studies that involve FA access.

In conclusion, the current study shows that sheep have an excellent tolerance for hindleg ischemia, similar to that seen in their carotid circulation. This makes the ovine model an excellent model to assess the outcome of cardiovascular interventions, both for models of femoral intervention, and for femoral access for angiography.
